title: Episode 92 â€“ Aaron William Perry, Regenerative Economics & Holiday Shopping
subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
description: Several of those folks have been guests on our podcast episodes. So I see at least three. I recognize it would be past podcast guests.
full_transcript:
[8.3s - 14.6s]: Hey friends, welcome to the Wyners Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry.

[15.6s - 23.0s]: Today we're doing a special Thanksgiving holiday shopping and regenerative economics episode.

[24.0s - 34.1s]: I thought I would share a few of the slides and key points that we use to help educate our Ambassador network.

[35.3s - 53.0s]: Also, I'm really excited to share with you a whole bunch of new affiliate partnerships that we've established here at the Wyners Community to support our community mobilization work and to bring you some amazing experiences.

[53.0s - 58.1s]: Wyners approved products for your holiday shopping and giving.

[59.2s - 70.5s]: And so I am so happy to share a lot of this with you. I've got a lot of fun products to show you and tell you about.

[70.5s - 79.2s]: And so before getting to those, by the way, there are going to be a number of discounts available for you on these products.

[80.1s - 84.6s]: And before showing you those, I thought I'd share a few slides.

[85.6s - 112.6s]: Like I said, that we use to talk about regenerative economics. What does that mean? How does that look and work? And how is that a key driving force in our global work together to restore and heal and create stewardship and regenerative oriented life ways and economies in our partnership networks all around the globe?

[113.6s - 117.2s]: So here we'll bring up some slides. There we go.

[118.3s - 135.2s]: So this is our Thanksgiving and holiday giving celebration episode. And you'll see here an image from a beautiful leadership summit that we hosted back in 2019.

[136.2s - 150.0s]: And this is right before a bunch of us were about to plant a number of baby blues bruises. You can see us holding those there and you'll probably recognize handful of faces in the picture there.

[150.2s - 160.8s]: Several of those folks have been guests on our podcast episodes. So I see at least three. I recognize it would be past podcast guests.

[162.5s - 184.7s]: And of course, we're talking about regenerative sustainability at all scales and permeating all aspects of our work and our lives, our family and community lives and our places of worship, our connection when we're out in nature, all of us are different aspects of our life here on this planet that we share.

[184.7s - 193.4s]: And regenerative sustainability and its deepest and most advanced form permeates all of those different dimensions.

[195.1s - 204.6s]: So when we get into the etymology of keywords that we use when we're talking about regenerative economics, there are four I want to share with you.

[204.6s - 222.2s]: And somebody's maybe familiar to you from past episodes and even if you've attended any of our training and education workshops. So the first is Oikos. And this is a Greek term and ancient Greek term that means home.

[223.0s - 245.8s]: And it turns out it's the root word from which our word Eko comes and this Eko is used in both ecology and economy. And so when we're using the word ecology or the word economy, we're really meaning understanding and taking care of our home and conducting the business of our home.

[246.9s - 257.6s]: The word humus is a proto-indoe European root hum and a Latin term from that origin meaning soil.

[258.6s - 269.9s]: And of course we love talking about the four keywords that relate to the same root which are humus, human, humor and humility.

[270.9s - 289.1s]: And as we share with our ambassador network, if we focus on those four key themes, it will likely improve our efficacy as community leaders, as educators and probably also improve our own personal health, well-being and quality of life.

[290.2s - 293.9s]: Weyley is a middle English word and it means well-being.

[295.1s - 308.5s]: Interesting. It's also the root word from which our word wealth is derived. And so when we're talking about wealth and its most advanced and sophisticated understanding, it means well-being.

[309.5s - 319.2s]: We know in a culture like ours at the moment, the notion of wealth can actually be very misleading and misunderstood.

[320.2s - 337.2s]: In fact, much of what we see in our world in terms of hyper consumerism, obsession with things like status and appearance, that the pursuit of those superficial forms of wealth actually often undermine well-being.

[338.5s - 348.4s]: And so we have a great inspiration of well-being with the notion of wealth, especially when we're thinking about communities that a lot of our work and opportunity lies.

[349.4s - 359.4s]: Finally is this awdema. This is a beautiful word in the ancient Hebrew language, meaning soil also, like humus.

[359.4s - 373.7s]: I mean soil or clay. And of course in the creation story found in our Judeo-Christian and Islamic roots with the creation of Adam or Adam from the soil, the awdema.

[374.5s - 385.7s]: This linguistic connection indicates our deep relationship with soil as human beings, as is also expressed in that Latin term humus.

[388.0s - 403.9s]: So when we're thinking about our home and our economics and our ecology, we can think in expanding circles in terms of spheres of influence. And of course in our own homes, it's likely that our influences is most acute and potent.

[404.9s - 415.7s]: And out from there, we're interacting with a number of different friends, stakeholders, colleagues, all kinds of folks affecting our entire world eventually.

[416.6s - 433.9s]: And so when we're thinking about regenerative economics and especially about what gifts we're choosing to give this holiday season, we can actually now orient our purchasing decisions and our activities in a way that is much more in service to the world.

[433.9s - 438.0s]: And then we can actually orient our business in terms of the ecology and to the communities all around the planet.

[438.9s - 458.6s]: Because we're talking ultimately about our shared home. And I love this in the context of Oikos. And yeah, of course a great marketing campaign thought this would be a good name for a yogurt also, but I invite you to think about this deeper meaning in terms of home that this Oikos points us toward.

[463.9s - 475.3s]: If we're talking about systems and companies and rules of the game that are supporting key activities that help balance and heal our world.

[476.2s - 489.6s]: And that help enhance our health and well being in the fine key topics globally speaking are decarbonizing energy, recarbonizing soil detoxifying our environments.

[489.6s - 502.8s]: This is broadly speaking kind of outside, if you will. Of course detoxifying our homes inside our local Oikos is important and regenerating ecosystems.

[503.0s - 510.3s]: And we've had several recent episodes speaking to the regenerative power of soil building.

[510.3s - 521.6s]: And what that means in terms of stabilizing climate in terms of boosting rural economies in terms of enhancing health and livelihoods of communities throughout the world.

[522.0s - 528.8s]: And in terms of cleaning up water and providing much more healthy and nutrient dense food to people.

[529.2s - 536.5s]: This regeneration function is perhaps we might say the most important really in a 21st century context.

[537.3s - 544.4s]: And of course to do all of this as intelligently as possible and with as much sophistication as possible.

[545.0s - 556.4s]: We're invited to really focus in on the love, the compassion, the caring. And you'll see I think in some of our partnerships that love, compassion and caring is really up the root of what we're doing.

[558.3s - 562.5s]: So great, we've got economics and consumer demand.

[563.6s - 574.8s]: Demand of course is one of the chapter titles in the book, Why on Earth. And I've got a copy right here that I'm planning to read a little excerpt from for you.

[576.3s - 589.7s]: Because when we're talking about regenerative economics, one of the key structural issues that is at the scale of the entire planet that we need to be looking at is who's serving whom?

[589.7s - 619.7s]: Have we conceptualized an economy where the earth and the natural resources of the earth and the people of the earth are effectively in service to the economy, which is effectively in service to the finance sector or alternatively might we be moving in the direction of understanding that intelligent finance is actually working in service to the economy, which is working in service to a certain extent.

[619.7s - 626.5s]: And we're also talking about our earth, all the living creatures of our shared ecology and the human family living here.

[628.3s - 643.6s]: So when we're focusing in on our consumer demand as one of the driving forces in an economy, it's clear it emerges that we're not just talking about technology when we're talking about stewardship and sustainability.

[643.6s - 660.5s]: We're also very much talking about a culture and consciousness that is shifting toward care and compassion regeneration stewardship that inside out heart centric approach is really key.

[661.9s - 690.5s]: So a real quick economics lesson, right? So if any of you studied most basic form of economics, you'd probably remember that we have in our sort of traditional post colonial economics, a very linear notion of value creation, which has actually been broken into four sectors or stages of value creation.

[691.6s - 698.3s]: And the economists call these primary secondary tertiary and quaternary, which essentially means first, second, third and fourth.

[699.0s - 714.7s]: So at that first stage, that primary stage, that's what we call production. So that might be harvesting timber in a forest. That might be harvesting fish from the sea. That might be growing and harvesting food.

[715.7s - 729.0s]: It might be mining and oil and gas extraction, right? It's essentially taking from the bounty of earth, whether it's renewable or non-renewable, that would all fall under the umbrella primary production.

[729.7s - 747.5s]: Secondary is where we add value. So now we're taking that timber from the forest and turning it into trees, excuse me, taking the trees and turning that into tables or chairs or paper or cards or even art, right?

[747.5s - 757.5s]: Or taking the fish and canning that for sale at the grocery store, taking the corn from the field and turning that into tortillas, for example.

[758.4s - 767.7s]: And then in the third stage, the tertiary stage is essentially where the commerce kicks in vis-a-vis the public, the general public.

[767.7s - 778.0s]: So that's where we'll see the retail shops and the online stores selling these products and also services for our purchase.

[778.9s - 790.3s]: And then the quaternary, the fourth stage of value creation is really the rarefied realms of information management of accounting and legal work and technology.

[790.3s - 818.7s]: And so there's also a sense of an advancing sort of complexity, although that's a very post-colonial understanding, because as we dive deeper and deeper into the science of ecology and understand the sophistication of soil, micro-organism structures, for example, we know that there is sophistication in the living biosphere of this planet that, frankly, dwarfs all of our human systems.

[819.6s - 824.9s]: Even notwithstanding our supercomputing and all of our advances in technology.

[825.8s - 831.8s]: So that's the linear notion of what an economic system looks like.

[831.9s - 843.7s]: And of course, coming out of a neocolonial era over the last few hundred years, this system has presumed, in many cases, slavery for labor sources.

[843.7s - 853.4s]: If not at least a labor pool that is not very well compensated or taken care of, frankly.

[853.9s - 857.0s]: And we see that all around the world today still.

[857.7s - 867.5s]: We see it in our own communities. We see it in other countries. We see it really at every kind of scale of economics throughout the world.

[867.5s - 873.5s]: And it's one of the things that many of us are working to heal and improve.

[874.3s - 881.1s]: So there's a social and an environmental component to everything that we're doing when we talk about regenerative economics.

[882.1s - 890.9s]: So this other diagram that you see, which is a circular diagram, is presenting a new way of thinking about economics.

[890.9s - 897.2s]: That is much more in harmony with the regenerative patterns we see here on the planet.

[898.3s - 916.7s]: And so instead of a four node linear extraction and value added framework, we're talking about closing the loop and adding a fifth node called the quintenary, which is where the regenerative stewardship knowledge, wisdom and expertise are housed.

[916.7s - 931.7s]: And where that human expertise is now directed back to the other four nodes so that at every step in all of our activities, we are doing an expert job of caring for people and for planet.

[932.7s - 938.8s]: One of the great thought leaders in this regenerative economic movement is John Fallerton.

[939.9s - 952.6s]: And at his organization, he imagines the dawn of the regenerative age in which we're focused on eight principles of a regenerative economy.

[952.6s - 963.0s]: And this is going to include being in right relationship. This is going to include viewing wealth holistically, right back to that notion of well being.

[963.7s - 972.6s]: It's going to include innovative adaptive and responsive problem solving these of some of the systemic challenges that we're facing.

[973.6s - 985.6s]: Empowered participation is key. It honors place and community and it's no accident that the chapter called place is the very first chapter in the book, Why on Earth.

[986.8s - 997.0s]: It focuses on the edge effect and on abundance, which is the natural condition of how life and biology works here on this planet.

[997.8s - 1005.6s]: Robust circulation, it means keeping things like currency circulating and not accumulating in different pockets.

[1006.7s - 1014.4s]: And of course, the eighth principle is seeking balance. We know balance is a key attribute of health and well being.

[1015.9s - 1034.4s]: So when we're digging into what economics means in a broader context of our culture, we understand that through our governance mechanisms, we have this feedback loop where policy is often influenced and often even controlled by certain economic interests.

[1035.4s - 1044.2s]: And that the rules of the game are established through that policy, right. And so when we talk about a free market economy, there really isn't no such thing, right.

[1044.3s - 1054.2s]: There are all kinds of rules and regulations from the tax code to various antitrust regulations, for example, environmental regulations.

[1054.3s - 1057.1s]: There are all kinds of rules that have been established.

[1058.1s - 1071.2s]: And those rules are going to help determine which companies out there are making great concentrated profits, which will feed back into the policy influence and control note.

[1071.9s - 1095.6s]: Now, at the note of the concentrating profits and financial capital, we're going to see another loop emerge. This is where the advertising and marketing influence is very much determining what many of us are going to purchase our consumer demand response and that is going to further drive capital and profits in certain directions.

[1096.3s - 1108.5s]: So we can see in the 20th century where there's been a whole lot of that happening in such a way that hasn't been very good for our planet or for ourselves, our health, our well being the health of our children and our communities.

[1109.0s - 1117.5s]: And certainly the health of many of the agriculture and manufacturing communities all around the planet. However, this is the same force.

[1117.5s - 1127.0s]: We can direct toward compassionate stewardship and regenerative oriented patterns and behaviors.

[1128.3s - 1144.9s]: And so when we overlay the 33 chapters of why on earth in this beautiful mandala, we can see that we actually have tremendous power to choose the products out there that are enhancing environmental sustainability enhancing social equity.

[1144.9s - 1156.3s]: And that we can't even launch and grow social enterprises companies whose products and services are specifically geared to enhancing that positive feedback loop.

[1158.0s - 1164.9s]: When we're talking about regenerative economics, we're necessarily also going to end up talking about money.

[1166.0s - 1173.8s]: And one of my very favorite books, The Future of Money, I recommend you check out if you're interested in diving deeper into this topic.

[1173.8s - 1194.2s]: Bernardo Lea, a friend of mine who passed last year was one of the technocratic team who created the convergence mechanism when many of the European countries were converting their natural national currencies into the euro couple a few decades ago.

[1194.8s - 1204.0s]: And so it was, you know, the French rock converting to the euro, the German, a Dogemark converting to the euro and so on.

[1205.0s - 1214.7s]: And Bernardo in this future of money is presents an incredible outlay of what's possible for our future and presents that in terms of four different scenarios.

[1215.4s - 1220.9s]: Two of them are really horrible and one of them is truly amazing and that's the one we're working toward.

[1221.8s - 1234.7s]: This is a quote here from Bernardo and it says greed and competition are not the result of immutable human temperament greed and fear of scarcity are in fact being created and amplified.

[1235.7s - 1257.4s]: The direct consequence is that we have to fight with each other in order to survive. So this is Bernardo recognizing that a big part of the mythology with which has informed our neo colonial economics is a mythology of scarcity and the mythology of competition, a mythology that says greed is good.

[1258.4s - 1263.8s]: And this is part of what we have to turn on its head in our work together.

[1265.2s - 1279.0s]: Because after all we're talking about the commons we're talking about our shared home, whether it's the water or the atmosphere or the climate or the environmental conditions of the places where we live and work.

[1279.0s - 1289.5s]: And the places where a whole lot of other humans are living and working this is what we share in common and this is what we are invited to steward.

[1290.9s - 1308.3s]: And so when we're thinking about some of these abstract economic models, let's just remember that we're talking about our own lives and the lives of millions of human beings around the planet and our environments and the lives of countless.

[1309.1s - 1318.1s]: Millions and billions of animals and other creatures that is what we're influencing every day with our purchasing decisions.

[1318.8s - 1328.8s]: It's as if whenever we buy anything we're sending signals all around the planet that are saying whatever we just bought we want somebody to make more of that.

[1328.8s - 1348.2s]: So when we're buying toxic products or products whose production technology means that toxicity is being spewed into regions and communities around the world, whenever we buy that one product we're sending a signal to the world say hey make more of that do more of that.

[1348.2s - 1364.0s]: And on the other hand when we're buying very non toxic environmentally safe socially conscious products we're sending those signals out there to the economy saying hey we want more of that and that's the power of consumer demand.

[1365.1s - 1378.0s]: In the book why on earth there are four chapters in particular demand work earn and give that speak to this power and I want to read a little excerpt for you.

[1379.0s - 1399.6s]: This is from Jared Diamond whose book Guns Germans and Steel is very well known and he subsequently wrote a book called Collapse looking at different cultures from around the world and from different periods of time that have appeared to collapse from an archaeological perspective.

[1399.6s - 1407.0s]: And in his research he found some common threads and themes leading to those collapses and here's what he says.

[1408.6s - 1427.3s]: To me the conclusion that the public has the ultimate responsibility for the behavior of even the biggest businesses is empowering and hopeful rather than disappointing my conclusion is not a moralistic one about who is right or wrong admirable or selfish a good guy or a bad guy.

[1427.3s - 1433.5s]: My conclusion is instead of prediction based on what I have seen happening in the past.

[1434.8s - 1450.9s]: Businesses have changed when the public came to expect and require different behavior to reward businesses for behavior that the public wanted and to make things difficult for businesses practicing behaviors that the public didn't want.

[1450.9s - 1461.5s]: I predict that in the future just as in the past changes in public attitudes will be essential for changes in businesses environmental practices.

[1462.5s - 1479.0s]: So that's Jared Diamond in his book Collapse speaking to the power of consumer demand the power we are wielding as individuals and families and communities regarding this massive global economy in which we're all connected.

[1481.2s - 1508.9s]: And so real quick two pillars we focus on at the Y honors community are thriving on the one hand and sustainability on the other and thriving has in it the five essential areas of personal practice that enhance the health and wellness of ourselves and our families and our neighborhoods in this has to do with food, the movement of our bodies connection with nature connection specifically with soil.

[1508.9s - 1520.1s]: And our well being practices that includes playing music practicing yoga perhaps meditating and so forth.

[1520.6s - 1530.8s]: Then on the sustainability side we have six core themes that pertain to the macro dynamics and systems in which we're all participating.

[1530.8s - 1541.8s]: And this is where we find stewardship and regeneration to be essential how we're doing energy and agriculture is absolutely critical and central to this.

[1542.5s - 1556.9s]: And of course choice which is another way of saying our demand our consumer demand our political demand that is driving so much and finally kindness you know we can fix all the technical challenges.

[1556.9s - 1566.6s]: But if we're not cultivating a culture of kindness we can very easily end up in a terrible situation.

[1567.0s - 1574.4s]: And I think it's obvious to most of us that we've seen way too little kindness in our culture as of late.

[1576.4s - 1579.7s]: We're talking about our global community.

[1581.9s - 1596.5s]: Brown, black, yellow, red, green, purple, whatever you know whatever our identities are whatever our ethnic heritage is our whatever indigenous peoples we come from all around the planet we are one human family.

[1598.4s - 1613.5s]: And speaking of one human family these are the 17 sustainable development goals we have established as one human family through the United Nations body where we convene as a global community.

[1614.7s - 1628.7s]: And you'll see that the number 17 goal the final goal is partnerships in collaboration and that is one of my very favorite because that is indeed a big part of what we're up to at the Y on earth community.

[1630.0s - 1653.6s]: And we are now launching our affiliate partnership program and we've already established these partnership connections with several wonderful companies many of these companies are being certified that's through the B corp certification regime many of them are providing products that are organic certified fair trade certified.

[1653.6s - 1683.6s]: And doing even more beyond that and that includes Purim Chelsea green the publisher Zen Bunny certified by dynamic coffee and they have chocolate to wail a waters which is our in house social enterprise where we're making all manner of biodynamically grown hemp infused soaking salts massage oils and sams earth hero which has an amazing array of products for your household.

[1683.6s - 1699.0s]: And you're able to use your business use there are herbals is doing incredible work with herbal medicine and mushroom based medicines they have an amazing Spatieric lab in Carbondale Colorado that was featured in a recent podcast episode.

[1699.0s - 1728.2s]: But earthwater press is another of our in house social enterprises publishing books and amplifying voices for our world growing spaces is a beautiful company making these geodesic greenhouse grow domes they've also been featured in a podcast episode recently of course soil works is a third in house social enterprise offering beautiful.

[1728.2s - 1728.9s]: So we're also able to make some of these wonderful.

[1729.2s - 1731.2s]: Potentized bio dynamic.

[1733.3s - 1750.6s]: Soil activation and fertilizer products and then finally last but not least is zeal optics and these guys are making wonderful sunglasses and goggles using plant based plastics and recycle plastics.

[1752.2s - 1780.6s]: So in our community of affiliate partners we're also launching our why on earth approved logo which is how we designate these companies that meet certain social and environmental standards now these next few slides are going to show you a bit of the products available and how you can get discounts when you're shopping and buying these products for upcoming gift giving for the holidays.

[1780.6s - 1810.5s]: And beyond so here's earth here they have over 7,000 sustainability products and you'll see in there they've got clothing shirts they got to go where bamboo utensils you can use instead of the disposable utensils of course with COVID that's even more important right now they've got all kinds of detergents that got socks and shirts and items for babies items for the pets all manner of household goods and goods you would use.

[1810.5s - 1820.5s]: And you're office in your house of worship you can get a 10% discount at earth here by following the link here and using the code why on earth.

[1821.2s - 1839.3s]: There are herbals of course our friends Tyler and Nicole are offering a beautiful line of Spajuric and herbal tinctures and of course the mushroom based supplements like the lions main you see in the image here they make beautiful sabs.

[1839.3s - 1852.8s]: And you can get a 10% discount with them at the vera herbals dot com slash partnerships slash wide dash on dash earth will have all the links in the show notes to for for ease of connecting.

[1863.1s - 1870.8s]: And you can get a 25% discount.

[1870.8s - 1900.4s]: And of course in these partnership and affiliate programs these companies are also giving a portion of the proceeds back to our nonprofit the wide earth community to help support our community mobilization work and to help support our podcast episode series so this is a great way not only to get the best healthiest most sustainable products for your gift giving but also

[1900.4s - 1907.9s]: to help give back to the wider community as you're doing that and it's a real win win as you're getting these great discounts.

[1909.1s - 1922.2s]: Here's Chelsea Green publishing they're publishing a whole array of home setting do it yourself fermenting organic agriculture regenerative agriculture books and resources.

[1922.2s - 1942.2s]: Chelsea Green dot com why OE 10 is the code you can use there for your 10% discount of course we just recently did an episode with the author Judith Schwartz whose book the reindeer chronicles a must read for those of us doing regenerative work was published by Chelsea Green.

[1943.2s - 1968.4s]: Here's growing spaces these are just beautiful greenhouse grottoes geodesic domes that are incredibly strong structurally speaking and so they have durability that goes above and beyond most greenhouse scenarios and products and can withstand tremendous hail and other weather that might be damaging as well as tremendous wind loads.

[1969.0s - 1992.3s]: You can go to growing spaces dot com slash why on earth to get a 5% discount now these are products that cost many thousands of dollars and so they're great for schools by the way and if you're connected with a school we can connect you directly with growing spaces to perhaps do an even better partnership deal because they are collaborating with many schools throughout the country.

[1992.3s - 2000.7s]: But just to get your dome for your own yard or community you'll get at least a 5% discount when you go through the why on earth link.

[2002.4s - 2018.8s]: Okay here's zeal me goodness we're really excited about our partnership with zeal these guys are really leading the way when it comes to plant based plastics and recycled plastics and they're very advanced goggles and sunglasses.

[2018.8s - 2025.7s]: You go to zeal opt dot link slash why on earth and you'll get a 10% discount on those products.

[2027.2s - 2041.8s]: Here's Zen Bunny and these guys are providing certified bio dynamic coffee which is just a tremendous offering and you can use the code why on earth to get a 10% discount with the Zen Bunny products.

[2041.8s - 2064.2s]: Okay here's way they water so I make these by hand and as we're scaling the business will be employ mothers and grandmothers to make these hemp infused soaking salts saps and massage and body oils to bring health and well being into all of our lives.

[2064.2s - 2091.0s]: And we are sourcing the hemp from biodynamic and organic farms throughout Colorado who are growing the CBD hemp in the cleanest and most potentized manner so that the medicinal properties of these infused oils and salts and saps are at a very high level of efficacy.

[2091.0s - 2107.5s]: Weather waters dot com is the website and we have lots of fun resources there talking about the difference aroma therapy blends and why those essential oils are bringing additional healing and well being properties to us.

[2107.5s - 2127.0s]: And if you use the code why on earth you'll get a 10% discount on all the way the water products now I want to mention to that we have monthly subscriptions available starting at $33 a month and this is a fabulous way to give the gift of wellness to friends and family for the holidays.

[2127.0s - 2149.6s]: When you sign up whoever is receiving the monthly shipment will get jars and and saps and 10 cent monthly to help maintain that regular practice of soaking and health and wellness it's so important for all of us and especially in these times.

[2151.9s - 2179.6s]: Soil works we're also making in house and if you go to soil works dot com and use the code why on earth you'll be getting 10% discounts there and these are potentized biodynamic blends for the garden for the farm the homestead and even your house plants and bringing additional health well being nutrition and microorganisms to the soil equal.

[2182.7s - 2206.9s]: Soil works is a beautiful product I really hope you guys will check that out now just brand new product offering we have are these beautiful hats we've got four different colors Pacific Navy blue chocolate salmon and all of green $33 per hat these hats are made with a hundred percent organic cotton and recycled polyester trucker style really cool.

[2207.5s - 2219.7s]: So you can get your 10% discount on those as well making it more like $30 a hat instead of 33 something like 29 when you go to why on earth dot org slash market and use the code why on earth.

[2220.9s - 2249.6s]: Of course at the why on earth dot org site we've got a lot of other beautiful products for soil and for community mobilization this is our community mobilization kit here that comes with video instructions documentation a copy of the soil stewardship handbook and a jar of the soil works bio dynamic soil activator so this is a whole kit you can use in your community and your neighborhood.

[2249.7s - 2262.8s]: Soil to activate soil with your neighbors your friends your colleagues we encourage you to check that out because when we're doing these soil activation stirs together which is what you see in the image on the left.

[2262.8s - 2292.5s]: It brings us all together causing us to engage in a very simple and beautiful ceremony of stewardship and regeneration and then we take the water into which we stirred the soil works product and then we sprinkle it all around the landscape into our gardens into our yards and of course because we're not working with anything toxic we get to stir this up with our hands and experience the direct benefits and serotonin producing.

[2293.3s - 2298.1s]: Consequences of interacting with those beneficial micro organisms that are in the product.

[2351.5s - 2377.1s]: Now we've got a poetry book available as well called poasis this is illustrated by my son Hunter who's now an architecture and environmental design student and I thought it would be fun to read you a poem out of here to celebrate our thanks giving time together and it's a poem called what if and I wrote this earlier this year.

[2436.3s - 2446.3s]: And it's one of my favorite poems that speaking to the fact that our future is really in our hands and that we're all in this together.

[2447.8s - 2465.3s]: We share one great home one great week us and as we cultivate a connection with place and we grow and water and harvest and cook and eat and work with our wastes and intelligent ways and steward and balance and unplug and walk and wonder and connect and delight and

[2488.5s - 2491.2s]: What will that look like.

[2566.8s - 2576.3s]: And it's interesting to think about the power of these times with our communication technologies and our access to information to knowledge to wisdom.

[2576.3s - 2587.1s]: And in one of my favorite essays called the meta industrial village written by William Irwin Thompson in a book collection of essays called darkness and scattered light.

[2604.5s - 2619.3s]: That is a hopeful statement. And I think it also implies as we become more and more aware and awake to this reality that we also understand our responsibility.

[2620.0s - 2630.1s]: And of course one of the beautiful ways in the time of holiday gift giving we can exercise that responsibility is through these beautiful partnerships and product offerings.

segments.text: Hey friends, welcome to the Wyners Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry.
Today we're doing a special Thanksgiving holiday shopping and regenerative economics episode.
I thought I would share a few of the slides and key points that we use to help educate our Ambassador network.

Also, I'm really excited to share with you a whole bunch of new affiliate partnerships that we've established here at the Wyners Community to support our community mobilization work and to bring you some amazing experiences.
Wyners approved products for your holiday shopping and giving.
And so I am so happy to share a lot of this with you. I've got a lot of fun products to show you and tell you about.
And so before getting to those, by the way, there are going to be a number of discounts available for you on these products.
And before showing you those, I thought I'd share a few slides.

Like I said, that we use to talk about regenerative economics. What does that mean? How does that look and work? And how is that a key driving force in our global work together to restore and heal and create stewardship and regenerative oriented life ways and economies in our partnership networks all around the globe?
So here we'll bring up some slides. There we go.
So this is our Thanksgiving and holiday giving celebration episode. And you'll see here an image from a beautiful leadership summit that we hosted back in 2019.
And this is right before a bunch of us were about to plant a number of baby blues bruises. You can see us holding those there and you'll probably recognize handful of faces in the picture there.
Several of those folks have been guests on our podcast episodes. So I see at least three. I recognize it would be past podcast guests.

And of course, we're talking about regenerative sustainability at all scales and permeating all aspects of our work and our lives, our family and community lives and our places of worship, our connection when we're out in nature, all of us are different aspects of our life here on this planet that we share.
And regenerative sustainability and its deepest and most advanced form permeates all of those different dimensions.
So when we get into the etymology of keywords that we use when we're talking about regenerative economics, there are four I want to share with you.

And somebody's maybe familiar to you from past episodes and even if you've attended any of our training and education workshops. So the first is Oikos. And this is a Greek term and ancient Greek term that means home.

And it turns out it's the root word from which our word Eko comes and this Eko is used in both ecology and economy. And so when we're using the word ecology or the word economy, we're really meaning understanding and taking care of our home and conducting the business of our home.
The word humus is a proto-indoe European root hum and a Latin term from that origin meaning soil.
And of course we love talking about the four keywords that relate to the same root which are humus, human, humor and humility.

And as we share with our ambassador network, if we focus on those four key themes, it will likely improve our efficacy as community leaders, as educators and probably also improve our own personal health, well-being and quality of life.
Weyley is a middle English word and it means well-being.
Interesting. It's also the root word from which our word wealth is derived. And so when we're talking about wealth and its most advanced and sophisticated understanding, it means well-being.
We know in a culture like ours at the moment, the notion of wealth can actually be very misleading and misunderstood.

In fact, much of what we see in our world in terms of hyper consumerism, obsession with things like status and appearance, that the pursuit of those superficial forms of wealth actually often undermine well-being.
And so we have a great inspiration of well-being with the notion of wealth, especially when we're thinking about communities that a lot of our work and opportunity lies.
Finally is this awdema. This is a beautiful word in the ancient Hebrew language, meaning soil also, like humus.
I mean soil or clay. And of course in the creation story found in our Judeo-Christian and Islamic roots with the creation of Adam or Adam from the soil, the awdema.
This linguistic connection indicates our deep relationship with soil as human beings, as is also expressed in that Latin term humus.

So when we're thinking about our home and our economics and our ecology, we can think in expanding circles in terms of spheres of influence. And of course in our own homes, it's likely that our influences is most acute and potent.
And out from there, we're interacting with a number of different friends, stakeholders, colleagues, all kinds of folks affecting our entire world eventually.

And so when we're thinking about regenerative economics and especially about what gifts we're choosing to give this holiday season, we can actually now orient our purchasing decisions and our activities in a way that is much more in service to the world.
And then we can actually orient our business in terms of the ecology and to the communities all around the planet.

Because we're talking ultimately about our shared home. And I love this in the context of Oikos. And yeah, of course a great marketing campaign thought this would be a good name for a yogurt also, but I invite you to think about this deeper meaning in terms of home that this Oikos points us toward.
If we're talking about systems and companies and rules of the game that are supporting key activities that help balance and heal our world.
And that help enhance our health and well being in the fine key topics globally speaking are decarbonizing energy, recarbonizing soil detoxifying our environments.
This is broadly speaking kind of outside, if you will. Of course detoxifying our homes inside our local Oikos is important and regenerating ecosystems.
And we've had several recent episodes speaking to the regenerative power of soil building.
And what that means in terms of stabilizing climate in terms of boosting rural economies in terms of enhancing health and livelihoods of communities throughout the world.
And in terms of cleaning up water and providing much more healthy and nutrient dense food to people.
This regeneration function is perhaps we might say the most important really in a 21st century context.
And of course to do all of this as intelligently as possible and with as much sophistication as possible.

We're invited to really focus in on the love, the compassion, the caring. And you'll see I think in some of our partnerships that love, compassion and caring is really up the root of what we're doing.
So great, we've got economics and consumer demand.
Demand of course is one of the chapter titles in the book, Why on Earth. And I've got a copy right here that I'm planning to read a little excerpt from for you.
Because when we're talking about regenerative economics, one of the key structural issues that is at the scale of the entire planet that we need to be looking at is who's serving whom?

Have we conceptualized an economy where the earth and the natural resources of the earth and the people of the earth are effectively in service to the economy, which is effectively in service to the finance sector or alternatively might we be moving in the direction of understanding that intelligent finance is actually working in service to the economy, which is working in service to a certain extent.
And we're also talking about our earth, all the living creatures of our shared ecology and the human family living here.

So when we're focusing in on our consumer demand as one of the driving forces in an economy, it's clear it emerges that we're not just talking about technology when we're talking about stewardship and sustainability.
We're also very much talking about a culture and consciousness that is shifting toward care and compassion regeneration stewardship that inside out heart centric approach is really key.

So a real quick economics lesson, right? So if any of you studied most basic form of economics, you'd probably remember that we have in our sort of traditional post colonial economics, a very linear notion of value creation, which has actually been broken into four sectors or stages of value creation.
And the economists call these primary secondary tertiary and quaternary, which essentially means first, second, third and fourth.

So at that first stage, that primary stage, that's what we call production. So that might be harvesting timber in a forest. That might be harvesting fish from the sea. That might be growing and harvesting food.

It might be mining and oil and gas extraction, right? It's essentially taking from the bounty of earth, whether it's renewable or non-renewable, that would all fall under the umbrella primary production.

Secondary is where we add value. So now we're taking that timber from the forest and turning it into trees, excuse me, taking the trees and turning that into tables or chairs or paper or cards or even art, right?
Or taking the fish and canning that for sale at the grocery store, taking the corn from the field and turning that into tortillas, for example.
And then in the third stage, the tertiary stage is essentially where the commerce kicks in vis-a-vis the public, the general public.
So that's where we'll see the retail shops and the online stores selling these products and also services for our purchase.
And then the quaternary, the fourth stage of value creation is really the rarefied realms of information management of accounting and legal work and technology.

And so there's also a sense of an advancing sort of complexity, although that's a very post-colonial understanding, because as we dive deeper and deeper into the science of ecology and understand the sophistication of soil, micro-organism structures, for example, we know that there is sophistication in the living biosphere of this planet that, frankly, dwarfs all of our human systems.
Even notwithstanding our supercomputing and all of our advances in technology.
So that's the linear notion of what an economic system looks like.
And of course, coming out of a neocolonial era over the last few hundred years, this system has presumed, in many cases, slavery for labor sources.
If not at least a labor pool that is not very well compensated or taken care of, frankly.
And we see that all around the world today still.
We see it in our own communities. We see it in other countries. We see it really at every kind of scale of economics throughout the world.
And it's one of the things that many of us are working to heal and improve.
So there's a social and an environmental component to everything that we're doing when we talk about regenerative economics.
So this other diagram that you see, which is a circular diagram, is presenting a new way of thinking about economics.
That is much more in harmony with the regenerative patterns we see here on the planet.

And so instead of a four node linear extraction and value added framework, we're talking about closing the loop and adding a fifth node called the quintenary, which is where the regenerative stewardship knowledge, wisdom and expertise are housed.
And where that human expertise is now directed back to the other four nodes so that at every step in all of our activities, we are doing an expert job of caring for people and for planet.
One of the great thought leaders in this regenerative economic movement is John Fallerton.
And at his organization, he imagines the dawn of the regenerative age in which we're focused on eight principles of a regenerative economy.
And this is going to include being in right relationship. This is going to include viewing wealth holistically, right back to that notion of well being.
It's going to include innovative adaptive and responsive problem solving these of some of the systemic challenges that we're facing.
Empowered participation is key. It honors place and community and it's no accident that the chapter called place is the very first chapter in the book, Why on Earth.
It focuses on the edge effect and on abundance, which is the natural condition of how life and biology works here on this planet.
Robust circulation, it means keeping things like currency circulating and not accumulating in different pockets.
And of course, the eighth principle is seeking balance. We know balance is a key attribute of health and well being.

So when we're digging into what economics means in a broader context of our culture, we understand that through our governance mechanisms, we have this feedback loop where policy is often influenced and often even controlled by certain economic interests.
And that the rules of the game are established through that policy, right. And so when we talk about a free market economy, there really isn't no such thing, right.
There are all kinds of rules and regulations from the tax code to various antitrust regulations, for example, environmental regulations.
There are all kinds of rules that have been established.
And those rules are going to help determine which companies out there are making great concentrated profits, which will feed back into the policy influence and control note.

Now, at the note of the concentrating profits and financial capital, we're going to see another loop emerge. This is where the advertising and marketing influence is very much determining what many of us are going to purchase our consumer demand response and that is going to further drive capital and profits in certain directions.

So we can see in the 20th century where there's been a whole lot of that happening in such a way that hasn't been very good for our planet or for ourselves, our health, our well being the health of our children and our communities.
And certainly the health of many of the agriculture and manufacturing communities all around the planet. However, this is the same force.
We can direct toward compassionate stewardship and regenerative oriented patterns and behaviors.

And so when we overlay the 33 chapters of why on earth in this beautiful mandala, we can see that we actually have tremendous power to choose the products out there that are enhancing environmental sustainability enhancing social equity.
And that we can't even launch and grow social enterprises companies whose products and services are specifically geared to enhancing that positive feedback loop.
When we're talking about regenerative economics, we're necessarily also going to end up talking about money.
And one of my very favorite books, The Future of Money, I recommend you check out if you're interested in diving deeper into this topic.

Bernardo Lea, a friend of mine who passed last year was one of the technocratic team who created the convergence mechanism when many of the European countries were converting their natural national currencies into the euro couple a few decades ago.
And so it was, you know, the French rock converting to the euro, the German, a Dogemark converting to the euro and so on.
And Bernardo in this future of money is presents an incredible outlay of what's possible for our future and presents that in terms of four different scenarios.
Two of them are really horrible and one of them is truly amazing and that's the one we're working toward.
This is a quote here from Bernardo and it says greed and competition are not the result of immutable human temperament greed and fear of scarcity are in fact being created and amplified.

The direct consequence is that we have to fight with each other in order to survive. So this is Bernardo recognizing that a big part of the mythology with which has informed our neo colonial economics is a mythology of scarcity and the mythology of competition, a mythology that says greed is good.
And this is part of what we have to turn on its head in our work together.

Because after all we're talking about the commons we're talking about our shared home, whether it's the water or the atmosphere or the climate or the environmental conditions of the places where we live and work.
And the places where a whole lot of other humans are living and working this is what we share in common and this is what we are invited to steward.

And so when we're thinking about some of these abstract economic models, let's just remember that we're talking about our own lives and the lives of millions of human beings around the planet and our environments and the lives of countless.
Millions and billions of animals and other creatures that is what we're influencing every day with our purchasing decisions.
It's as if whenever we buy anything we're sending signals all around the planet that are saying whatever we just bought we want somebody to make more of that.

So when we're buying toxic products or products whose production technology means that toxicity is being spewed into regions and communities around the world, whenever we buy that one product we're sending a signal to the world say hey make more of that do more of that.

And on the other hand when we're buying very non toxic environmentally safe socially conscious products we're sending those signals out there to the economy saying hey we want more of that and that's the power of consumer demand.
In the book why on earth there are four chapters in particular demand work earn and give that speak to this power and I want to read a little excerpt for you.

This is from Jared Diamond whose book Guns Germans and Steel is very well known and he subsequently wrote a book called Collapse looking at different cultures from around the world and from different periods of time that have appeared to collapse from an archaeological perspective.
And in his research he found some common threads and themes leading to those collapses and here's what he says.

To me the conclusion that the public has the ultimate responsibility for the behavior of even the biggest businesses is empowering and hopeful rather than disappointing my conclusion is not a moralistic one about who is right or wrong admirable or selfish a good guy or a bad guy.
My conclusion is instead of prediction based on what I have seen happening in the past.

Businesses have changed when the public came to expect and require different behavior to reward businesses for behavior that the public wanted and to make things difficult for businesses practicing behaviors that the public didn't want.
I predict that in the future just as in the past changes in public attitudes will be essential for changes in businesses environmental practices.

So that's Jared Diamond in his book Collapse speaking to the power of consumer demand the power we are wielding as individuals and families and communities regarding this massive global economy in which we're all connected.

And so real quick two pillars we focus on at the Y honors community are thriving on the one hand and sustainability on the other and thriving has in it the five essential areas of personal practice that enhance the health and wellness of ourselves and our families and our neighborhoods in this has to do with food, the movement of our bodies connection with nature connection specifically with soil.
And our well being practices that includes playing music practicing yoga perhaps meditating and so forth.
Then on the sustainability side we have six core themes that pertain to the macro dynamics and systems in which we're all participating.
And this is where we find stewardship and regeneration to be essential how we're doing energy and agriculture is absolutely critical and central to this.
And of course choice which is another way of saying our demand our consumer demand our political demand that is driving so much and finally kindness you know we can fix all the technical challenges.
But if we're not cultivating a culture of kindness we can very easily end up in a terrible situation.
And I think it's obvious to most of us that we've seen way too little kindness in our culture as of late.
We're talking about our global community.

Brown, black, yellow, red, green, purple, whatever you know whatever our identities are whatever our ethnic heritage is our whatever indigenous peoples we come from all around the planet we are one human family.
And speaking of one human family these are the 17 sustainable development goals we have established as one human family through the United Nations body where we convene as a global community.

And you'll see that the number 17 goal the final goal is partnerships in collaboration and that is one of my very favorite because that is indeed a big part of what we're up to at the Y on earth community.

And we are now launching our affiliate partnership program and we've already established these partnership connections with several wonderful companies many of these companies are being certified that's through the B corp certification regime many of them are providing products that are organic certified fair trade certified.

And doing even more beyond that and that includes Purim Chelsea green the publisher Zen Bunny certified by dynamic coffee and they have chocolate to wail a waters which is our in house social enterprise where we're making all manner of biodynamically grown hemp infused soaking salts massage oils and sams earth hero which has an amazing array of products for your household.

And you're able to use your business use there are herbals is doing incredible work with herbal medicine and mushroom based medicines they have an amazing Spatieric lab in Carbondale Colorado that was featured in a recent podcast episode.

But earthwater press is another of our in house social enterprises publishing books and amplifying voices for our world growing spaces is a beautiful company making these geodesic greenhouse grow domes they've also been featured in a podcast episode recently of course soil works is a third in house social enterprise offering beautiful.
So we're also able to make some of these wonderful.
Potentized bio dynamic.
Soil activation and fertilizer products and then finally last but not least is zeal optics and these guys are making wonderful sunglasses and goggles using plant based plastics and recycle plastics.

So in our community of affiliate partners we're also launching our why on earth approved logo which is how we designate these companies that meet certain social and environmental standards now these next few slides are going to show you a bit of the products available and how you can get discounts when you're shopping and buying these products for upcoming gift giving for the holidays.

And beyond so here's earth here they have over 7,000 sustainability products and you'll see in there they've got clothing shirts they got to go where bamboo utensils you can use instead of the disposable utensils of course with COVID that's even more important right now they've got all kinds of detergents that got socks and shirts and items for babies items for the pets all manner of household goods and goods you would use.
And you're office in your house of worship you can get a 10% discount at earth here by following the link here and using the code why on earth.

There are herbals of course our friends Tyler and Nicole are offering a beautiful line of Spajuric and herbal tinctures and of course the mushroom based supplements like the lions main you see in the image here they make beautiful sabs.
And you can get a 10% discount with them at the vera herbals dot com slash partnerships slash wide dash on dash earth will have all the links in the show notes to for for ease of connecting.
And you can get a 25% discount.

And of course in these partnership and affiliate programs these companies are also giving a portion of the proceeds back to our nonprofit the wide earth community to help support our community mobilization work and to help support our podcast episode series so this is a great way not only to get the best healthiest most sustainable products for your gift giving but also
to help give back to the wider community as you're doing that and it's a real win win as you're getting these great discounts.
